column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=3 .
#Text=Discussion

#Text=Lignocellulosic biomass residues constitute an abundant , renewable source of energy-rich polysaccharides that , when subjected to enzymatic hydrolysis , are transformed into oligomeric and monomeric sugars .

#Text=The latter can either be processed through chemical and/or biological treatment towards a repertoire of high added-value products or , depending on their structural properties , to be used as animal feed or human dietary supplements with prebiotic properties .
#Text=Many tons of forest materials are annually made available by the forest industry and these residual streams are usually under-valorized .

#Text=Biomass from birch trees consists of approximately 43.9 % w/w cellulose , while this percentage reaches 42 % w/w for spruce trees , underlining the great potential of these residues towards the production of COS.

#Text=It has been already reported in the literature that COS produced by enzymatic hydrolysis of wheat straw , comprised of 84 % of cellobiose , showed a substantial improvement of the microbial consortium of weaned pigs .
#Text=However , limited studies on production of COS from forest biomass have yet been reported .

#Text=Production of non-digestible COS from forest residual biomass includes a complete process starting from physicochemical pretreatment and fractionation in order to obtain a cellulose-rich solid pulp , followed by controlled enzymatic hydrolysis in order to increase the ratio of oligomers over monomers , product recovery and purification and , eventually , evaluation of prebiotic activity .

#Text=To the best of our knowledge , this is the first study to report the optimization of parameters for tuning the performance of the commercial cocktail Celluclast® towards the production of oligosaccharides and , moreover , this is one of the first reports that describes the whole procedure covering from the pretreatment/fractionation to the in vitro evaluation of COS prebiotic potential on Lactobacilli strains .
#Text=Lignocellulose degradation is a challenging process due a number of factors linked with the recalcitrance and complex nature of this material .
#Text=The saccharification of the lignocellulosic biomass is hence limited due to these factors .

#Text=Particularly , the hemicellulose and lignin removal , the decrease of the degree of polymerization of the cellulose chain and the decrease of the cellulose crystallinity index , which is also accompanied by the decrease of the particle size and thus the increase of the accessible surface area , are considered as major requirements for a hydrolysis process to be efficient .

#Text=Therefore , to boost the hydrolysis of lignocellulose towards the production of prebiotic oligosaccharides , there is a necessity to overcome the difficulty and complexity of the depolymerization of this substrate .
#Text=Applying an efficient pretreatment/fractionation method , such as organosolv process , has proven a promising solution , particularly by employing food-grade aqueous ethanol solutions .
#Text=Combining an efficient fractionation process with controlled enzymatic hydrolysis can boost the release of oligomers over monomers .
#Text=Synthesis of cellobiose and other oligosaccharides with higher DP is also possible through enzyme-mediated condensation reaction of monosaccharides , catalyzed by β-glucosidases .
#Text=However , the reaction rate is quite slow , leading to very low oligosaccharide yields and thus , making the process not economically viable .
#Text=Compared to synthesis , hydrolysis of cellulose-containing substrates , including lignocellulosic residues , is an attractive alternative .

#Text=The main bottleneck of the process is the end-product inhibition , which is more severe in case of cellobiohydrolases but can also affect many enzymatic activities that are present in a cellulase mixture .
#Text=Additionally , the remaining hemicellulose-derived products on the substrate , like xylan , also impact the hydrolysis rates of cellulases .

#Text=Even though generally the inhibition is more apparent at high-solid concentrations it is also significant at low-solid concentrations and therefore can occur under the conditions of the present study .
#Text=To eliminate the adverse effects of the end-product inhibition , we studied the effect of buffer exchange on the increase of cellobiose yields .
#Text=A similar strategy described as a multistage degradation process of cellulose towards the production of cellobiose has been also reported in the literature .

#Text=This process is expected not only to alleviate the inhibitory reactions from present cellobiose and glucose , but also to enable the removal of unbound β-glucosidase in the washing fraction , while other cellulases containing a carbohydrate binding module ( CBM ) remain attached onto the substrate and continue the hydrolysis process .
#Text=Moreover , we studied the addition of the β-glucosidase inhibitor conduritol-B-epoxide at different concentrations , which led to a substantial increase of the final cellobiose produced .
#Text=Finally , modifying the reaction conditions and performing the hydrolysis at pH 7.0 resulted in a high ratio of CB : Glu .

#Text=This is in accordance with data reported in the literature describing that activity of Celluclast® against pNP-glucopyranoside ( indicative of β-glucosidase activity ) is observed only in a narrow pH range between 4.0 – 5.5 .
#Text=By combining buffer exchange with addition of conduritol and changing the pH of the reaction , we achieved a CB : Glu ratio of 21.8 , which is the highest among those reported .

#Text=Ultrafiltration in order to remove the enzymes and possibly re-use them , combined with nanofiltration in order to remove glucose , conduritol and other low-molecular-weight compounds was also employed for the scale-up reactions .
